properties.name: Coney Island/Sheepshead Bay
properties.text: Coney Island was once separated from mainland Brooklyn by a marshy creek. In 1902 rails were used to bring waste to the site and by 1913, the island was liked with the mainland. The photo below shows the construction of Emmons Ave, a 1936 WPA project, on top of former landfill near Sheepshead Bay.

properties.name: Fresh Kills
properties.text: In 1948, the last untouched area of marshland in the city was turned into a landfill.  Staten Island's Fresh Kills marshland had originally opened as a temporary site, but grew into the largest landfill in the world during its operation. In 2001, the landfill was officially closed, although the covering and installation of gas and groundwater management systems continues to this day.

properties.name: JFK Airport
properties.text: Robert Moses is responsible for many of the large refuse-based projects in New York City including Idlewild Airport (now JFK Airport). This project was under the banner of his "Sanitation, Reclamation, Recreation" plan. Over 3,500 acres of land was filled in the construction of this project.

properties.name: Corona Meadows
properties.text: During the 1930s, the city's waste disposal policy outlined a clear plan for using the city's waste to fill marshland to be sites for infrastructure for the city's growing population. In Corona, 1,200 acres of marshland was filled and turned into the site for the 1939 World's Fair.

properties.name: Ravenswood
properties.text: Ravenswood was a barge-fed landfill in the late 19th century. At that time, solid waste in New York City was comprised mostly of coal and ash from wood burning stoves. Putrescible waste accounted for a very small portion of the total waste.

properties.name: Jamaica Bay
properties.text: In 1905, a city report commented on the almost unlimited supply of dumping grounds at the marshlands of Jamaica Bay. As the city's population grew, so did it's need for space to dispose of its waste. By the 1960s, the landfills at Jamaica Bay had begun to expand beyond the existing marshes and into the bay itself.

properties.name: Newtown Creek
properties.text: Much of the landfilling in the late 19th century took place along shorelines in order to create bulkheads capable of supporting marine access for industry and commerce. This photo shows Newtown Creek in 1939 as a bustling site for industrial uses on the bulkheads.

properties.name: Riker's Island
properties.text: Riker's Island was part of the sanitary landfill movement that was seen as as technological fix to the problem of trash. Refuse was buried under a layer of soil, thus containing it and making it available for productive use. In 1924 all barge-fed waste was brought to the island and after 14 years of use, Riker's Island had grown to more than twice its original size and became home to a population of rats - some the size of cats - and spontaneous fires and explosions so that the ground resembled a sea of small volcanoes. At it's peak, the island's waste heaps reached over 100 feet above sea level. After much of the waste was moved to construct LaGuardia airport, the island became the site of the city's jail in 1935 and many early buildings on the site, still in use today, suffer structural damage from being built on unstable soil.

properties.name: Red Hook
properties.text: This image shows a squatter's colony on the site of a dump in Red Hook in 1931.

properties.name: Pelham Bay Park
properties.text: Under Robert Moses' "Sanitation, Reclamation, Recreation" plan, Orchard Beach was created from a barge-fed landfill with sand added from Sandy Hook, New Jersey and the Rockaways. The landfill connected two former islands to the mainland and was turned into a public beach.
